subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: Anthony: I fear that a lot of your concern over how well QS works in practice is due to inexperience on the part of many of the people who are members of this
messageBody:
Anthony:

I fear that a lot of your concern over how well QS works in practice is due to inexperience on the part of many of the people who are members of this list.  I seldom have to give any thought to which TH sound to write.  And if I do occasionally hesitate, it is only for a moment.  I cam sure that the reason for occasional hesitation is that we all learned TO which doesn't make the distinction between the two letters.  If children are taught QS in the future, they won't hesitate at all over which TH to use.  It certainly is not enough of a problem to justify throwing one of the TH letters out of the alphabet. 

Ooze and wool are quite distinct from each other and cause me no problem either.  My father pronounces Gary Cooper's name with the wool sound, and I use ooze.  We still manage to communicate.  I don't believe we should throw one sound out as that makes the alphabet less accurate in its representation of speech.  I especially like your terminology "...provides the comfort of one letter per sound" as if that is some sort of compromise.  Isn't that how an alphabet is supposed to work?   If we throw ooze or wool out, then every time I come across that letter in a word, I have to decide which pronunciation it is supposed to have in this particular instance.

I understand that for fast reading, we want to limit spelling variants to a reasonable number.  But I still believe that the number of variants will be low enough that it will not cause a significant reading speed diminution, and I believe this is borne out by the experience of the early QS writers.  Moira could address that point as well.  Everyone doesn't have to spell every word the same.

If I can read "why" written without a wh sound as we now have in the QS News, I'm sure a person who doesn't use wh can read why written with it.  Throwing out wh will just annoy the people to whom it is important.  Frankly, I don't think they would agree to it.  I know I won't.

For those who merge awe, on and ox or some subset thereof, let them spell all these words with on or however they want to.  It will look peculiar to me, but I can figure it out just as I'm sure they will figure out what I am talking about. 

By the way, I also pronounce the "l" in the middle of "palm" and "calm".  A "pom" is what I call my dog (Pomeranian).

Loch and Llan don't bother me one way or the other.  They exist in the QS manual, but I've never had the need for them.  They can sit there and not bother anybody.  If a font designer leaves them out of his font, the vast majority of people won't care.

Paige


Anthony Grahn wrote:

There seem to be several letter pairs (or triads) that stimulate
discussion namely Thaw vs They, Ooze vs Foot, Way vs Way , Ox vs Awe
vs Ah.

If I understand the underlying point, it is this: the difference in
these letters aid reading in some accents and provide the comfort of
one letter per sound (grapheme-phoneme correspondence) in certain
accents, but these pairings have drawbacks; typically they hinder
witting and cause some confusion in other accents.

Thaw-They is the most conspicuous. Nearly everyone hears a difference
in these letters and yet must hesitate when writing to decide which to
use. The problem is even worse for those who have the F sound for TH
and now must figure out which letter to use for a sound they don't
have. But the advantage of having two letters appears to be small: I
suspect that reading would not be hindered if only one such letter
existed for both. And a visually ambiguity between They vs She has
been mentioned which can not be helping reading.

For Ooze vs Foot the same issue exists: writing is encumbered for a
small benefit to reading apperantly.

And again for Way vs Why.

Ox vs Awe vs Ah: thanks to lexical sets, there should theoretically be
less confusion for those who merge some or all of those sounds yet
clearly they still cause a great deal of conversation. And for these
there are difficulties beyond just slowing writing. Yet the benefits
of having a three part division seem only to be aesthetic and then
only for certian accents.

Then there are other letters that have very specialized use: Loch and
LLan never appear in any English word and so can only be used for
Scottish and Welsh place names. But why only add these sounds? There
are several places where Anglophones live integrated with
non-Anglophones. Should then there not be a battery of French vowels
in QS for Quebec place names and likewise Nunavut sounds for names in
northern Canada. And sounds for Aboriginal Australian place names and
Native American Indian place names?

Without raising the issue of changing QS I'd put the question thus: if
a new writing system for English were being composed, would it include
this particular set of letters?

--- In Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...>
